title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Intensive Care Unit (ICU)

Bladder catheter removed → check that bladder empties properly
Chest tube removed (day 2-4) → follow-up x-ray
Fluid emptied from drains every few hours
Start tube feedings by feeding
Feeding jejunostomy (stays in 8 weeks)

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Ward - 6Tower

Jejunostomy feeds started
Up in a chair most of the day
Walking in the halls

Start with assistance
Improves lung function
Prevents loss of muscle strength

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Jejunostomy Feeds
Jejunostomy tube feeds

Start continuous (24 hours)
Convert to night-time only (16 hours)

Water administered through feeding tube

Usually 8oz 4 times/day
Important to prevent dehydration

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Jejunostomy Tube



Nutrition to bypasses the esophagus and stomach
Placed in small intestine
Pump administers feedings slowly
Feeding done at night

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Jejunostomy Typical Regimen

Jejunostomy tube feeds for 16 hours (6pm-10am)

Men: 75mL/hour x 16 hours = 5 cartons
Women: 60mL/hour x 16 hours = 4 cartons

Water 240ml (8oz) via syringe 4x/day

Hospital nurses will teach use of the feeding tube

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Jejunostomy Feeds with Diabetes
Jejunostomy feedings elevate blood sugars

Insulin may be required along with feeds

Typical Pattern for tube feeds

Feeds run via pump from 6pm to 10am
Insulin at 6pm (70/30 insulin)
Insulin at Midnight (70/30 insulin)
No insulin if tube feedings are not run

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Jejunostomy Video


A video is available to help become familiar with the feeding jejunostomy

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Activity after Surgery

Up in chair most of the day
Walking with help from nurse/Physical Therapist
Goals:

Improve lung function
Prevent muscle loss

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Nasogastric (NG) Tube
Tube passed through nose into stomach

Drains fluid from stomach
Prevents vomiting

Upper GI X-ray on 2nd or 3rd day after surgery

If stomach empties well \(\rightarrow\) NG tube removed
Otherwise, X-ray repeated 2-3 days later

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Swallowing Evaluation
Once NG tube has been removed:
Modified barium swallow in radiology

Drink a white chalky liquid (barium)
Look for proper swallowing function
70% of patients \(\Rightarrow\) liquids started by mouth

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Oral Intake at Home
Most are taking protein shakes when they go home
Protein shakes are started after tolerating water


2 oz per hour to start
4 oz per hour if 2oz are tolerated well

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Discharge
Goal: ready to leave day #6/7 after surgery

Night-time tube feedings (6pm to 10am)
Nutrition by mouth (70% of patients)

1 oz of water per hour by mouth OR
Protein shakes 4oz every 2 hours

Water through tube 8oz four times per day
Home care nursing (feeding tube teaching)
Home infusion (tube feeding supplies)

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Nutrition after Surgery
At discharge home:

Protein shakes 4oz every 2 hrs
Tube feeds 4-5 cans at night (6pm-10am)

10-12 Days: Increase protein shakes

Tube feeds 3-4 cans at night

Three weeks: Post-esophagectomy Diet
8-12 weeks: Remove feeding tube (in office)

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Transition from Tube Feeds \(\rightarrow\) Eating
Dietitian will calculate daily protein goal

Typically 60-75 grams protein/day
Each carton of tube feeding has 15 grams

75 grams protein = 5 cartons/night

More intake by mouth \(\rightarrow\) tube feeds reduced

Spread out protein during the day (20gm/meal)

Three meals + 2-3 high-protein snacks

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Post-esophagectomy Diet

Soft Consistency
High Protein
Avoid sugary liquids (can cause ‘dumping’)
Avoid raw vegetables (and salads)
Eating

Small, frequent meals
Sit up for 30-45 minutes after eating
Avoid eating within 2 hours of bedtime

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Medicines at Home - Pain
Acetaminophen (Tylenol) 1000mg 4x/day
Gabapentin 300mg 3 times/day
Oxycodone

As needed in addition to Tylenol/gabapentin
Will begin reducing dose at first postop visit
Can usually discontinue by 4 weeks
NO DRIVING WHILE ON OXYCODONE

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Non-steroidals Anti Inflammatory (NSAID)
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatories (Celebrex)

200 mg every 12 hours starting at 2 weeks

NO GOODY POWDERS OR BCs

(Can cause permanent scarring at the surgery site)

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Acid Blockers = Proton Pump Inhibitors
Examples include ompeprazole and pantoprazole

Will stay on for at 1-2 years to prevent acid reflux
Important in preventing scarring at anastomosis (new connection between esophagus and stomach)
To administer through feeding tube, open capsule and resuspend beads in 60mL (2oz) of water

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Medicines at Home
Reglan – Helps stomach empty

Will plan to stop after six weeks
0.1% risk of tardive dyskinesia (nervous tic)

Remeron – Helps improve appetite

Can cause vivid dreams
Used for several weeks after surgery
Will stop within first three months of surgery

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Metoprolol = Beta Blockers

Slows heart rate and lowers blood pressure

Used to prevent rapid heart rate
Patients not taking a beta blocker prior to surgery \(\rightarrow\) wean after after surgery
Patients taking a beta blockerprior to surgery \(\rightarrow\) return to prior dose and drug after surgery

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Sleeping at Home


Reflux can occur the first few weeks/months after surgery
This improves over the first few months
A wedge pillow can be helpful for sleep

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Postoperative Visit at 7-10 Days
Check surgical site

Remove staples (if needed)

Adjust medicines as needed

Insulin (for diabetic patients on insulin)
Reduce beta blocker medicines

Advance diet
Reduce tube feeds

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
After surgery
Wean off medicines added after surgery

Pain medicines
Beta-blockers
Reglan and Remeron

Continue acid blockers for at least 1 year

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Jejunostomy Removal
Jejunostomy tube is removed in the office once you can take in enough nutrients by mouth
Removal usually around 8 weeks after surgery
May take 30 minutes and some local anesthetic to loosen up the tube for removal.

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Nutritional Monitoring after Surgery
You may have difficulty absorbing some nutrients:

Iron
Vitamin B12
Vitamin D

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Nutritional Monitoring after Surgery
About 3 months after the jejunostomy tube is removed, we will check blood levels:

Iron (ferritin)
Vitamin B12
Vitamin D

title: Early-Stage Cancer of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Nutritional Replacements after Surgery
Vitamin or iron replacements can be ordered by:

Primary Care Provider (PCP)
Medical Oncologist
Surgeon

If levels are low

Replacement
Repeat testing in 3-6 months

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
section: 4 Treatment is guided by the Stage of cancer
text:
4 Treatment is guided by the Stage of cancer
The treatment recommended will depend upon the stage of the cancer. If you haven’t already, this may be a good time to view the video on Diagnosis and Staging.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
5 Staging
A PET or CT scan is used for staging. If the scans show that the tumor is localized, without signs of spread beyond the nearby lymph nodes, it is considered M0.
On the other hand, if the scans show signs of spread, this is considered M1.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
6 Metastatic DIsease = M1
Patients with metastatic disease are best treated with chemotherapy and are generally not treated with surgery

We will focus in this video on Locally-advanced Esophageal cancer

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
section: 8 Locally-advanced Esophageal Cancer T2/3 or N+.
text:
8 Locally-advanced Esophageal Cancer T2/3 or N+.
Locally advanced esophageal cancer has not spread to other organs in the body. Locally-advanced cancers are either T2 or T3 or node-positive and are M0
If this terminology is not familiar to you, please refer to our video on Diagnosis and Staging. There is a link above and in the description below.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
9 Locally-advanced: M0
Locally-advanced cancers are M0, which means there is no evidence of metastasis, or spread to other parts of the body.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
10 Adenocarcinoma vs Squamous Cell.
To make things a bit more complicated, there are two types of esophageal cancer: Adenocarcinoma and Squamous Cell Carcinoma. The treatment of there cancers is somewhat similar, but different enough that we have prepared a video to specifically address squamous cell carcinoma.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
11 Types of Esophageal Cancer
This video will focus on locally-advanced adenocarcinoma

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
section: 12 Why not just Cut it out?
text:
12 Why not just Cut it out?
I am occasionally asked by patients why we don’t just remove esophageal cancer with surgery as the first treatment.
The answer is a bit complex.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
13 
When a patient is diagnosed with cancer of the esophagus or gastroesophageal junction, it can look like the cancer is confined to the esophagus.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
15 
If surgery is performed as the only therapy for locally-advanced cancer,

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
16 
there is a risk that cancer cells can be left behind

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
17 Locally Advanced
Preoperative therapy is administered before surgery And is designed to shrink the tumor

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
18 Locally Advanced
and kill cancer cells in the surrounding area
This therapy typically involves chemotherapy

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
19 Locally Advanced
and may involve radiation

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
20 Locally Advanced
The overall goal is shrinking the tumor and killing nearby cancer cells, to make the surgery more effective

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
21 Surgery
After preoperative therapy has shrunk the tumor and any other cancer cells, surgery can be performed

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
22 Post Surgery
Preoperative therapy combined with surgery offers the best chance to remove all of the cancer, without leaving any behind

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
23 Post Surgery and Reconstruction
…without leaving any cancer cells behind

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
24 Preoperative Therapy 4
To summarize, preoperative therapy:

Shrinks the tumor
Make surgery more effective
Leads to better cancer control than surgery alone

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
25 Neoadjuvant
You may hear preoperative therapy referred to as “neoadjuvant therapy”

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
26 Preop Therapy
For adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, there are two different approaches to preoperative therapy.
One uses chemotherapy and radiation together, followed by surgery

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
27 Preop Therapy
The other uses chemotherapy before and after surgery, without radiation therapy

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
28 Chemotherapy + Radiation -> Surgery
The chemotherapy and radiation strategy uses chemotherapy and radiation together
Chemotherapy is given intraveneously once per week
Radiation is given five days per week
Both are administered together for 5 1/2 weeks
This is also know as the “CROSS” treatment regimen

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
29 Chemotherapy + Radiation -> Surgery
The chemotherapy is a low dose, designed to make the radiation more effective
The therapy is generally well tolerated
Hair loss is uncommon
Low blood counts are also uncommon, and occur in about 7% of cases

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
30 Esophagitis
The radiation can, however, cause inflammation in the esophagus called esophigitis.
This can make eating more uncomfortable during the last two weeks of radiation
The good news is that this is temporarily and usually resolves within 2 or 3 weeks after the radiation is completed.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
31 Esophagitis
What this may mean, however, is placement of a temporary feedindg tube may be needed.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
32 Esophagitis
If a feeding tube is necessary, it can usually be removed by 3 weeks after the end of radiation.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
33 Chemo + Radiation -> Surgery 2
To summarize, This approach to preoperative therapy uses six weeks of chemotherapy and radiation together.
Surgery is typically performed 6-8 weeks after the end of radiation, as soon as patients have recovered.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
34 (4) Adenocarcinoma Preoperative Therapy 4
The second and somewhat newer approach to preoperative therapy for esophgeal adenocarcinoma is treatment with chemotherapy, followed by surgery, followed by additional chemotherapy
Chemtherapy is given every other week for 4 doses,
Followed by surgery,
Followed by chemotherapy every other week for another 4 doses

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
35 Chemo -> Surgery -> Chemo
Chemotherapy is administered intravenously every other week for 4 doses over 8 weeks
Surgery is then performed 4-6 weeks later
Chemotherapy is again administered intravenously every other week for 4 more doses over 8 weeks

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
36 Chemotherapy Options
There are two commonly used “recipes” for chemotherapy:
FLOT consists of four drugs
FOLFOX consists of three drugs

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
37 Chemotherapy OPtions
As you might expect, FLOT is more effective against cancer, while FOLFOX has fewer side effects

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
38 Durvalumab Immunotherapy.
Durvalumab is a drug which activates the immune system to fight cancer
The combination of FLOT and Durvalumab appears to be more effective than FLOT alone
Durvalumab is typically given along with FLOT chemotherapy, followed by monthly doses

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
39 Chemo -> Surgery -> Chemo 2
To summarize, the chemotherapy strategy calls for 4 doses of chemotherapy before surgery, and an additional 4 doses of chemotherapy afterwards.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
40 (2) Preoperative Therapy 4
If we compare Chemotherapy + Radiation (or CROSS) with chemotherapy (FLOT)..
We see that Chemotherapy + Radiation has fewer side effects, but FLOT chemotherapy is more effective
A central venous port is required for FLOT chemotherapy
Due to radiation esophagitis, a feeding tube is a little more likely to be needed with chemotherapy and radiation

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
41 ChemoRT vs Chemo
Your medical oncologist will guide you in the decision regarding chemotherapy + radiation vs chemotherapy alone.
In general, FLOT is recommended for younger and healthier patients
While chemotherapy and radiation is recommended for patients who may have difficulty tolerating FLOT

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
42 Preparing for Preoperative Therapy (42)
Nutrition during therapy is important to get through the treatment. We have a video about nutrition
Exercise is important to prevent loss of muscle mass, which can increase the risk of surgery
If you need any dental work done, it’s important to check with your dentist about removing any potential source of infection

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
43 Preparing for Preoperative Therapy- (43)
In some cases, a feeding tube may be needed
A central venous port is frequently needed for chemotherapy administration

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Adenocarcinoma
text:
44 Wrap up 1

GIST

Starts from wall of stomach
Slow growing

Adenocarcinoma

Conventional “stomach cancer”
Starts from lining of stomach
Can spread to lymph nodes
More aggressive

title: GI Stromal Tumors of the Stomach
text:
GIST: Benign or Malignant?
GIST tumors have a range of behavior:

Small tumors tend to behave in a benign manner but can grow over time
Larger tumors tend to behave in a malignant (cancerous) manner

Initial treatment usually surgery
Risk of recurrence determined by pathology
Size of tumor
Mitotic rate = how rapidly tumor is dividing

Oral drug shrinks GIST tumors
Well tolerated
Given after surgery for high-risk tumors

1 or 3 years depending upon risk

Given before surgery for large tumors

title: Patient Education
text:
Surgery for Esophageal Cancer
Surgery for esophageal cancer is performed for:

Superficial Tumors (T1) not removed by endoscopy
Localized Tumors (T2 N0 M0)
Locally Advanced (T3 M0) after preop therapy

title: Patient Education
text:
Goals of Surgery



Remove tumor from esophagus
Remove surrounding lymph nodes
Create a new esophagus

title: Patient Education
text:
Ivor Lewis (Transthoracic) Esophagectomy



Removes tumor and lower 1/3 esophagus
Removes surrounding lymph nodes
GI tract reconstructed

title: Patient Education
text:
Reconstruction


New esophagus is created from the stomach in the abdomen by fashioning it into a tube.

title: Patient Education
text:
Ivor Lewis esophagectomy


The new esophagus is now brought up into the chest. A connection is made between the esophagus and the stomach, called an anastomosis.

title: Patient Education
text:
Minimally-invasive Ivor Lewis



Small incisions abdomen and chest
Surgical telescope and instruments
Smaller incisions \(\rightarrow\) faster recovery and less discomfort

title: Patient Education
text:
Open Ivor Lewis


Mininally-invasive approach feasible in 95% of cases
In some cases, an open approach is still necessary.

title: Patient Education
text:
Total Esophagectomy


For patients with tumors in the upper esophagus, we need to remove more of the esophagus
We need to remove the whole esophagus, including the portion in the neck

title: Patient Education
text:
McKeown Esophagectomy


 All of esophagus removed

 Connection made in the neck

title: Patient Education
text:
Risks of Esophagectomy
Esophagectomy is a complex operation, with a real risk of complications.
Two significant complications:

Anastomotic leak
Pneumonia

title: Patient Education
text:
Anastomotic Leak


The anastomosis is surgical connection between the esophagus and the stomach.

title: Patient Education
text:
Anastomotic Leak


If healing doesn’t occur:

Leakage of fluid from the esophagus
Infection in the space between the lungs
Requires additional time in the hospital

title: Patient Education
text:
Anastomotic Leak


If leak occurs:

Some leaks will seal
Stent may be required to help healing
Occasionally additional surgey is required

title: Patient Education
text:
Anastomotic Leak


Risk of leak depends on:

Type of operation performed
Nutritional status of patient
Experience of the surgeon

title: Patient Education
text:
Pneumonia



Occurs in 10-15% of patients after esophagectomy.
Requires treatment with antibiotics
Requires a longer hospitalization.

title: Patient Education
text:
Preventing Pneumonia
Several ways to help prevent pneumonia:

Deep breathing
Coughing
Walking

After surgery, this means:

Sitting in a chair most of the day
Walking in the halls as soon as possible

title: Patient Education
text: Minimally-invasive Esophagectomy

title: Patient Education
text:
Risks of Surgery
Risks related to anesthesia

Heart attack (5%)
Irregular heart rhythm (15%)
Pneumonia (10%)
Blood clots in legs (<5%)
Pulmonary embolism (2%)

title: Patient Education
text:
Risks of Surgery
Risks related to Surgery

Anastomotic leak (5%)
Stricture at anastomosis (15%)
Death within 90 days of surgery

Low risk patients = 2%
Intermediate risk = 10%
High risk = 30%

title: Patient Education
text:

Risks of Death within 90 Days of Surgery

title: Patient Education
text:
Day Prior to Surgery

Clear liquids for 24 hours prior to surgery
Check with Pre-op nurse regarding medicines day prior to surgery
No tube feedings the night before surgery

title: Patient Education
text:
Day of Surgery

Arrive at 5am – nothing to eat or drink after midnight.
Medicines OK w/ a sip of water
sip of black coffee but no cream.
Surgery will be cancelled if you have cream/milk
Waiting room for family and friends on 5th floor

title: Patient Education
text:
Epidural Catheter for Pain Control

Remains in place for 2-5 days
Dosage can be adjusted as needed
Can make it more difficult to urinate
May require foley catheter in bladder
Foley catheter removed after epidural removed

title: Patient Education
text:
Intensive Care Unit (ICU) (2-4 days)

Surgical ICU on 11th floor
NG tube in nose to drain stomach and esophagus
Catheter in bladder

I’m Dr Jonathan Salo, I’m a GI Cancer Surgeon.
.font60[If you’re seeing this video, it’s likely because you or someone you know as had a recent diagnosis of esophageal cancer.]
This video is designed to help you choose a surgeon and hospital for your esophagectomy surgery.
When it comes to surgery for esophageal cancer, we’re all interested in getting the best outcome possible. The goals of any operation are rapid recovery, being able to return to activities, and a low risk of complications.
Esophageal surgery is a substantial operation, so it’s even more important to increase the chances of a good outcome.
There are several factors which can change the odds of a good outcome:
Patient factors
Hospital and the Surgeon

When you choose a surgeon or a hospital for your cancer surgery, you want to find the best chance of success. You want to make sure you have the best players on the field, and you want to maximize your chances of winning.
Unfortunately, there aren’t baseball cards for hospitals and surgeons, and finding the statistics for a hospital or surgeon can be a challenge, but it’s still important that you have all the information you need to make a good decision.

title: Your Surgery Team
text:
Hospital Volume
Practice makes perfect in many things in life, and esophageal surgery is no exception.
Hospitals where an esophagectomy is performed more frequently in general have better outcomes than hospitals where the operation is only occasionally done.

This chart shows the relationship between hospital volume and the risk of death after esophagectomy.

title: Your Surgery Team
text:
The risk of death after esophagectomy is about twice as high in hospitals which perform less than 5 esophagectomy operations per year.










The easiest way to find out whether a hospital is high volume or low volume is to ask your surgeon.
You could also check the internet. The Leapfrog Group is a non-profit organization that collects and publishes safety information healthcare. Their website ranks hospitals for safety and can help you find a high-volume hospital.

You can find a link to the Leapfrog website in the description: HospitalSafetyGrade.org
You can search on a hospital. Once there, you can click “View this hospital’s leapfrog Hospital Survey Results”

Of course there are low-volume hospital that have good outcomes, but starting with a high-volume hospital is a place to start.

section: Genetics of Hereditary Diffuse Gastric Cancer
text:
Genetics of Hereditary Diffuse Gastric Cancer

Altered copy of the CDH1 gene found to be responsible
We each carry two copies of the CDH1 gene

Altered copy is passed on to half of children

Family members with the altered CDH1 gene tend to develop cancer

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
Clinically Apparent Gastric Cancer
Among patients with HDGC who have visible stomach cancer, this is termed “clinically apparent”

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
Cancer Risk in HDGCd
Among family members in HDGC families with an altered CDH1 gene:

Men have 70% risk of stomach cancer by age 80
Women have 50-80% risk of stomach cancer by age 80

Increased risk of endometrial cancer

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:

Blood test can detect copies of the altered CDH1 gene
Recommended in all patients under age 50 with stomach cancer
Requires meeting with a genetic counselor

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:

Preventive surgery to remove the stomach can be performed
Surgery dramatically reduces risk of gastric cancer
Surgery is usually done before age 40

text:

If preventive surgery is performed, 90-95% of cases have microscopic tumor in the removed stomach

text:
Hereditary Diffuse Gastric Cancer
Inherited condition in which an altered copy of the CDH1 gene is passed from generation to generation

Affected person can pass the gene to (on average) half of their children
Affected persons carry the CDH1

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:

Affected individuals have microscopic cancers beginning to form in the top layer of the stomach at an early age
Majority of affected individuals will develop visible cancer by age 40

text:
CDH1

Among patients with CDH1 mutation and a family history of gastric cancer who undergo preventive total gastrectomy, 90% have early stages of gastric cancer

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
Hereditary Diffuse Gastric Cancer

Genetic condition in which family members have high rates of gastric cancer
Most affected members develop gastric cancer by age 40
Affected family members pass the susceptibility to half their children

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
section: Genetics of Hereditary Diffuse Gastric Cancer
text:
Genetics of Hereditary Diffuse Gastric Cancer

Altered copy of the CDH1 gene found to be responsible
We each carry two copies of the CDH1 gene

Altered copy is passed on to half of children

Family members with the altered CDH1 gene tend to develop cancer

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
Clinically Apparent Gastric Cancer
Among patients with HDGC who have visible stomach cancer, this is termed “clinically apparent”

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
Cancer Risk in HDGCd
Among family members in HDGC families with an altered CDH1 gene:

Men have 70% risk of stomach cancer by age 80
Women have 50-80% risk of stomach cancer by age 80

Increased risk of endometrial cancer

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
Genetic Testing

Blood test can detect copies of the altered CDH1 gene
Recommended in all patients under age 50 with stomach cancer
Requires meeting with a genetic counselor

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
Prophylactic Gastrectomy in HDGC

Preventive surgery to remove the stomach can be performed
Surgery dramatically reduces risk of gastric cancer
Surgery is usually done before age 40

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
Prophylactic Gastrectomy in HDGC
Among family members with HDGC who carry the CDH1 gene
If preventive surgery is performed, 90-95% of cases have microscopic tumor in the removed stomach

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
Hereditary Diffuse Gastric Cancer
Inherited condition in which an altered copy of the CDH1 gene is passed from generation to generation
Presence of the gene can be detected by genetic testing
Affected person can pass the gene to (on average) half of their children
Affected persons carry the CDH1

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
Hereditry Diffuse Gastric Cancer
Affected individuals have microscopic cancers beginning to form in the top layer of the stomach at an early age
Majority of affected individuals will develop visible cancer by age 40
By age 80, 70% of men and 56-83% of women are estimated to be at risk to develop visible cancer however some recent studies place this risk at 50%/33%

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
CDH1
CDH1 carriers with visible cancer are termed “clinically apparent”
CDH1 carriers with clinically apparent cancers which are large enough to cause symptoms generally are likely to have spread to lymph nodes at the time of diagnosis

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
Prophylactic Gastrectomy

Recommended for CDH1 carriers between ages 18-40
Cancer rarely is found to have spread to lymph nodes
Requires removing all of stomach tissue

title: Stomach Cancer and CDH1 Gene
text:
CH1 and Family History
Among patients with CDH1 mutation and a family history of gastric cancer who undergo preventive total gastrectomy, 90% have early stages of gastric cancer
Among patients with CDH1 mutation without a family history of gastric cancer, 2 out of 3 (67%) are estimated to have early stages of gastric cancer

title: Patient Education
text:
Cancer Staging
Staging refers to the tests to determine

How large is the tumor?
Has there been spread to lymph nodes?
Has it spread to other parts of the body?

Treatment options depend upon the cancer stage

title: Patient Education
text:
Cancer Staging

T = Tumor - Depth of growth into the wall


N = Nodes - Spread to the lymph nodes


M = Metastasis - Spread to liver, lungs, or bone

title: Patient Education
text:
Early Stage Cancers




Cancers start on the very inside layer called the mucosa

title: Patient Education
text:
Locally-advanced Cancers




Over time, cancers can grow into the muscular wall

title: Patient Education
text:
Lymph Nodes




In some cases, cancer cells can break off from the main tumor and spread to lymph nodes

title: Patient Education
text:
T Stage




Cancers are categorized based upon the thickness of the tumor, known as the T stage

title: Patient Education
text:
N Stage


Cancers are categorized by whether there is spread to the nodes.

N0 cancers have not spread to the nodes
N1 cancers have spread to the nodes.

title: Patient Education
text:
M Stage


Some cancers spread to other parts of the body

M0 cancers have not spread to other parts of the body
M1 cancers have spread lungs, liver, or bone

Similar to CT scan
Tracer shows ‘hot spots’

Cancer

Normal organs (heart, kidneys)

text:

Ultrasound in scope

title: Patient Education
text:
Day Prior to Surgery

Clear liquids for 24 hours prior to surgery
Check with Pre-op nurse regarding medicines day prior to surgery
No tube feedings the night before surgery

title: Patient Education
text:
Day of Surgery

Arrive at 5am – nothing to eat or drink after midnight.
Medicines OK w/ a sip of water
sip of black coffee but no cream.
Surgery will be cancelled if you have cream/milk
Waiting room for family and friends on 5th floor

title: Patient Education
text:
Epidural Catheter for Pain Control

Remains in place for 2-5 days
Dosage can be adjusted as needed
Can make it more difficult to urinate
May require foley catheter in bladder
Foley catheter removed after epidural removed

title: Patient Education
text:
Intensive Care Unit (ICU) (2-4 days)

Surgical ICU on 11th floor
NG tube in nose to drain stomach and esophagus
Catheter in bladder
Chest tube right chest
Abdominal drains (usually 2)
Feeding jejunostomy (usually stays in 8 wks)

title: Patient Education
text:
Intensive Care Unit (ICU)

Bladder catheter removed → check that bladder empties properly
Chest tube removed (day 2-4) → follow-up x-ray
Fluid emptied from drains every few hours
Start tube feedings by feeding
Feeding jejunostomy (stays in 8 weeks)

title: Patient Education
text:
Ward - 6Tower

Jejunostomy feeds started
Up in a chair most of the day
Walking in the halls

Start with assistance
Improves lung function
Prevents loss of muscle strength

title: Patient Education
text:
Jejunostomy Feeds
Jejunostomy tube feeds

Start continuous (24 hours)
Convert to night-time only (16 hours)

Water administered through feeding tube

Usually 8oz 4 times/day
Important to prevent dehydration

title: Patient Education
text:
Jejunostomy Tube



Nutrition to bypasses the esophagus and stomach
Placed in small intestine
Pump administers feedings slowly
Feeding done at night

title: Patient Education
text:
Jejunostomy Typical Regimen

Jejunostomy tube feeds for 16 hours (6pm-10am)

Men: 75mL/hour x 16 hours = 5 cartons
Women: 60mL/hour x 16 hours = 4 cartons

Water 240ml (8oz) via syringe 4x/day

Hospital nurses will teach use of the feeding tube

title: Patient Education
text:
Jejunostomy Feeds with Diabetes
Jejunostomy feedings elevate blood sugars

Insulin may be required along with feeds

Typical Pattern for tube feeds

Feeds run via pump from 6pm to 10am
Insulin at 6pm (70/30 insulin)
Insulin at Midnight (70/30 insulin)
No insulin if tube feedings are not run

title: Patient Education
text:
Jejunostomy Video


A video is available to help become familiar with the feeding jejunostomy

title: Patient Education
text:
Activity after Surgery

Up in chair most of the day
Walking with help from nurse/Physical Therapist
Goals:

Improve lung function
Prevent muscle loss

title: Patient Education
text:
Nasogastric (NG) Tube
Tube passed through nose into stomach

Drains fluid from stomach
Prevents vomiting

Upper GI X-ray on 2nd or 3rd day after surgery

If stomach empties well \(\rightarrow\) NG tube removed
Otherwise, X-ray repeated 2-3 days later

title: Patient Education
text:
Swallowing Evaluation
Once NG tube has been removed:
Modified barium swallow in radiology

Drink a white chalky liquid (barium)
Look for proper swallowing function
70% of patients \(\Rightarrow\) liquids started by mouth

title: Patient Education
text:
Oral Intake at Home
Most are taking protein shakes when they go home
Protein shakes are started after tolerating water


2 oz per hour to start
4 oz per hour if 2oz are tolerated well

title: Patient Education
text:
Discharge
Goal: ready to leave day #6/7 after surgery

Night-time tube feedings (6pm to 10am)
Nutrition by mouth (70% of patients)

1 oz of water per hour by mouth OR
Protein shakes 4oz every 2 hours

Water through tube 8oz four times per day
Home care nursing (feeding tube teaching)
Home infusion (tube feeding supplies)

title: Patient Education
text:
Nutrition after Surgery
At discharge home:

Protein shakes 4oz every 2 hrs
Tube feeds 4-5 cans at night (6pm-10am)

10-12 Days: Increase protein shakes

Tube feeds 3-4 cans at night

Three weeks: Post-esophagectomy Diet
8-12 weeks: Remove feeding tube (in office)

title: Patient Education
text:
Transition from Tube Feeds \(\rightarrow\) Eating
Dietitian will calculate daily protein goal

Typically 60-75 grams protein/day
Each carton of tube feeding has 15 grams

75 grams protein = 5 cartons/night

More intake by mouth \(\rightarrow\) tube feeds reduced

Spread out protein during the day (20gm/meal)

Three meals + 2-3 high-protein snacks

title: Patient Education
text:
Post-esophagectomy Diet

Soft Consistency
High Protein
Avoid sugary liquids (can cause ‘dumping’)
Avoid raw vegetables (and salads)
Eating

Small, frequent meals
Sit up for 30-45 minutes after eating
Avoid eating within 2 hours of bedtime

title: Patient Education
text:
Medicines at Home - Pain
Acetaminophen (Tylenol) 1000mg 4x/day
Gabapentin 300mg 3 times/day
Oxycodone

As needed in addition to Tylenol/gabapentin
Will begin reducing dose at first postop visit
Can usually discontinue by 4 weeks
NO DRIVING WHILE ON OXYCODONE

title: Patient Education
text:
Non-steroidals Anti Inflammatory (NSAID)
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatories (Celebrex)

200 mg every 12 hours starting at 2 weeks

NO GOODY POWDERS OR BCs

(Can cause permanent scarring at the surgery site)

title: Patient Education
text:
Acid Blockers = Proton Pump Inhibitors
Examples include ompeprazole and pantoprazole

Will stay on for at 1-2 years to prevent acid reflux
Important in preventing scarring at anastomosis (new connection between esophagus and stomach)
To administer through feeding tube, open capsule and resuspend beads in 60mL (2oz) of water

title: Patient Education
text:
Medicines at Home
Reglan – Helps stomach empty

Will plan to stop after six weeks
0.1% risk of tardive dyskinesia (nervous tic)

Remeron – Helps improve appetite

Can cause vivid dreams
Used for several weeks after surgery
Will stop within first three months of surgery

title: Patient Education
text:
Metoprolol = Beta Blockers

Slows heart rate and lowers blood pressure

Used to prevent rapid heart rate
Patients not taking a beta blocker prior to surgery \(\rightarrow\) wean after after surgery
Patients taking a beta blockerprior to surgery \(\rightarrow\) return to prior dose and drug after surgery

title: Patient Education
text:
Sleeping at Home


Reflux can occur the first few weeks/months after surgery
This improves over the first few months
A wedge pillow can be helpful for sleep

title: Patient Education
text:
Postoperative Visit at 7-10 Days
Check surgical site

Remove staples (if needed)

Adjust medicines as needed

Insulin (for diabetic patients on insulin)
Reduce beta blocker medicines

Advance diet
Reduce tube feeds

title: Patient Education
text:
After surgery
Wean off medicines added after surgery

Pain medicines
Beta-blockers
Reglan and Remeron

Continue acid blockers for at least 1 year

title: Patient Education
text:
Jejunostomy Removal
Jejunostomy tube is removed in the office once you can take in enough nutrients by mouth
Removal usually around 8 weeks after surgery
May take 30 minutes and some local anesthetic to loosen up the tube for removal.

title: Patient Education
text:
Nutritional Monitoring after Surgery
You may have difficulty absorbing some nutrients:

Iron
Vitamin B12
Vitamin D

title: Patient Education
text:
Nutritional Monitoring after Surgery
About 3 months after the jejunostomy tube is removed, we will check blood levels:

Iron (ferritin)
Vitamin B12
Vitamin D

title: Patient Education
text:
Nutritional Replacements after Surgery
Vitamin or iron replacements can be ordered by:

Primary Care Provider (PCP)
Medical Oncologist
Surgeon

If levels are low

Replacement
Repeat testing in 3-6 months

title: Central Venous Port
text:
Most chemotherapy is administered by vein.
Several options exist to administer chemotherapy:

Intravenous catheter in peripheral veins
Peripheral Intravenous Central Catheter (PICC)
Central Venous port

title: Central Venous Port
text:
Most chemotherapy is administered by vein.
Several options exist to administer chemotherapy:

Intravenous catheter in peripheral veins
Peripheral Intravenous Central Catheter (PICC)
Central Venous port

title: Central Venous Port
text:
Intravenous Catheter in Peripheral Vein (“IV”)



IV catheter placed in vein of hand or arm
Allows administration of chemo and fluids
Placed for each dose
Removed that day
Not suitable for FLOT chemo

title: Central Venous Port
text:
Central Venous Port



Implantable device makes chemo easier
May shower in 24 hrs
No special care at home
OK for FLOT chemo
Allows for blood draws

title: Central Venous Port
text:
Central Venous Port



Implanted under skin
Neck incision (1/4”)
Incision below the collarbone
Sutures dissolve
“Superglue” on incisions

title: Central Venous Port
text:
Central Venous Port


When it is time for chemotherapy, a needle is inserted through the skin into the port

title: Central Venous Port
text:
Laparoscopy



Some stomach cancers can spread inside the abdomen
Areas of spread can be very small (grain of rice)
Laparoscopy can detect spread inside the abdomen

title: Central Venous Port
text:
Laparoscopy



General anesthetic
Several 1/4” incisions
Telescope examines the abdomen
Biopsies can be performed.

Staging refers to the tests to determine

How large is the tumor?

Has it spread to other parts of the body?

Treatment options depend upon the cancer stage

T = Tumor - Depth of growth into the wall


N = Nodes - Spread to the lymph nodes


M = Metastasis - Spread to liver, lungs, or bone

N0 cancers have not spread to the nodes

Reduces risk of complications from treatment

Start slowly and build up

text:
Surgery for Esophageal Cancer
Surgery for esophageal cancer is performed for:

Superficial Tumors (T1) not removed by endoscopy
Localized Tumors (T2 N0 M0)
Locally Advanced (T3 M0) after preop therapy

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Goals of Surgery



Remove tumor from esophagus
Remove surrounding lymph nodes
Create a new esophagus

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Ivor Lewis (Transthoracic) Esophagectomy



Removes tumor and lower 1/3 esophagus
Removes surrounding lymph nodes
GI tract reconstructed

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Reconstruction


New esophagus is created from the stomach in the abdomen by fashioning it into a tube.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Ivor Lewis esophagectomy


The new esophagus is now brought up into the chest. A connection is made between the esophagus and the stomach, called an anastomosis.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Minimally-invasive Ivor Lewis



Small incisions abdomen and chest
Surgical telescope and instruments
Smaller incisions \(\rightarrow\) faster recovery and less discomfort

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Open Ivor Lewis


Mininally-invasive approach feasible in 95% of cases
In some cases, an open approach is still necessary.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Total Esophagectomy


For patients with tumors in the upper esophagus, we need to remove more of the esophagus
We need to remove the whole esophagus, including the portion in the neck

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
McKeown Esophagectomy


 All of esophagus removed

 Connection made in the neck

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Risks of Esophagectomy
Esophagectomy is a complex operation, with a real risk of complications.
Two significant complications:

Anastomotic leak
Pneumonia

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Anastomotic Leak


The anastomosis is surgical connection between the esophagus and the stomach.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Anastomotic Leak


If healing doesn’t occur:

Leakage of fluid from the esophagus
Infection in the space between the lungs
Requires additional time in the hospital

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Anastomotic Leak


If leak occurs:

Some leaks will seal
Stent may be required to help healing
Occasionally additional surgey is required

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Anastomotic Leak


Risk of leak depends on:

Type of operation performed
Nutritional status of patient
Experience of the surgeon

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Pneumonia



Occurs in 10-15% of patients after esophagectomy.
Requires treatment with antibiotics
Requires a longer hospitalization.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Preventing Pneumonia
Several ways to help prevent pneumonia:

Deep breathing
Coughing
Walking

After surgery, this means:

Sitting in a chair most of the day
Walking in the halls as soon as possible

sip of black coffee but no cream.

Surgical ICU on 11th floor

Bladder catheter removed → check that bladder empties properly

Feeding jejunostomy (stays in 8 weeks)

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Nasogastric (NG) Tube
Tube passed through nose into stomach

Drains fluid from stomach
Prevents vomiting

Upper GI X-ray on 2nd or 3rd day after surgery

If stomach empties well \(\rightarrow\) NG tube removed
Otherwise, X-ray repeated 2-3 days later

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Swallowing Evaluation
Once NG tube has been removed:
Modified barium swallow in radiology

Drink a white chalky liquid (barium)
Look for proper swallowing function
70% of patients \(\Rightarrow\) liquids started by mouth

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Oral Intake at Home
Most are taking protein shakes when they go home
Protein shakes are started after tolerating water


2 oz per hour to start
4 oz per hour if 2oz are tolerated well

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Discharge
Goal: ready to leave day #6/7 after surgery

Night-time tube feedings (6pm to 10am)
Nutrition by mouth (70% of patients)

1 oz of water per hour by mouth OR
Protein shakes 4oz every 2 hours

Water through tube 8oz four times per day
Home care nursing (feeding tube teaching)
Home infusion (tube feeding supplies)

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Nutrition after Surgery
At discharge home:

Protein shakes 4oz every 2 hrs
Tube feeds 4-5 cans at night (6pm-10am)

10-12 Days: Increase protein shakes

Tube feeds 3-4 cans at night

Three weeks: Post-esophagectomy Diet
8-12 weeks: Remove feeding tube (in office)

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Transition from Tube Feeds \(\rightarrow\) Eating
Dietitian will calculate daily protein goal

Typically 60-75 grams protein/day
Each carton of tube feeding has 15 grams

75 grams protein = 5 cartons/night

More intake by mouth \(\rightarrow\) tube feeds reduced

Spread out protein during the day (20gm/meal)

Three meals + 2-3 high-protein snacks

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Post-esophagectomy Diet

Soft Consistency
High Protein
Avoid sugary liquids (can cause ‘dumping’)
Avoid raw vegetables (and salads)
Eating

Small, frequent meals
Sit up for 30-45 minutes after eating
Avoid eating within 2 hours of bedtime

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Medicines at Home - Pain
Acetaminophen (Tylenol) 1000mg 4x/day
Gabapentin 300mg 3 times/day
Oxycodone

As needed in addition to Tylenol/gabapentin
Will begin reducing dose at first postop visit
Can usually discontinue by 4 weeks
NO DRIVING WHILE ON OXYCODONE

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Non-steroidals Anti Inflammatory (NSAID)
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatories (Celebrex)

200 mg every 12 hours starting at 2 weeks

NO GOODY POWDERS OR BCs

(Can cause permanent scarring at the surgery site)

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Acid Blockers = Proton Pump Inhibitors
Examples include ompeprazole and pantoprazole

Will stay on for at 1-2 years to prevent acid reflux
Important in preventing scarring at anastomosis (new connection between esophagus and stomach)
To administer through feeding tube, open capsule and resuspend beads in 60mL (2oz) of water

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Medicines at Home
Reglan – Helps stomach empty

Will plan to stop after six weeks
0.1% risk of tardive dyskinesia (nervous tic)

Remeron – Helps improve appetite

Can cause vivid dreams
Used for several weeks after surgery
Will stop within first three months of surgery

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Metoprolol = Beta Blockers

Slows heart rate and lowers blood pressure

Used to prevent rapid heart rate
Patients not taking a beta blocker prior to surgery \(\rightarrow\) wean after after surgery
Patients taking a beta blockerprior to surgery \(\rightarrow\) return to prior dose and drug after surgery

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Sleeping at Home


Reflux can occur the first few weeks/months after surgery
This improves over the first few months
A wedge pillow can be helpful for sleep

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Postoperative Visit at 7-10 Days
Check surgical site

Remove staples (if needed)

Adjust medicines as needed

Insulin (for diabetic patients on insulin)
Reduce beta blocker medicines

Advance diet
Reduce tube feeds

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
After surgery
Wean off medicines added after surgery

Pain medicines
Beta-blockers
Reglan and Remeron

Continue acid blockers for at least 1 year

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Jejunostomy Removal
Jejunostomy tube is removed in the office once you can take in enough nutrients by mouth
Removal usually around 8 weeks after surgery
May take 30 minutes and some local anesthetic to loosen up the tube for removal.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Nutritional Monitoring after Surgery
You may have difficulty absorbing some nutrients:

Iron
Vitamin B12
Vitamin D

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Nutritional Monitoring after Surgery
About 3 months after the jejunostomy tube is removed, we will check blood levels:

Iron (ferritin)
Vitamin B12
Vitamin D

Primary Care Provider (PCP)
Medical Oncologist
Surgeon

If levels are low

Replacement
Repeat testing in 3-6 months

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Goals of Surgery



Remove tumor from esophagus
Remove surrounding lymph nodes
Create a new esophagus

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Ivor Lewis (Transthoracic) Esophagectomy



Removes tumor and lower 1/3 esophagus
Removes surrounding lymph nodes
GI tract reconstructed

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Reconstruction


New esophagus is created from the stomach in the abdomen by fashioning it into a tube.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Ivor Lewis esophagectomy


The new esophagus is now brought up into the chest. A connection is made between the esophagus and the stomach, called an anastomosis.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Minimally-invasive Ivor Lewis



Small incisions abdomen and chest
Surgical telescope and instruments
Smaller incisions \(\rightarrow\) faster recovery and less discomfort

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Open Ivor Lewis


Mininally-invasive approach feasible in 95% of cases
In some cases, an open approach is still necessary.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Total Esophagectomy


For patients with tumors in the upper esophagus, we need to remove more of the esophagus
We need to remove the whole esophagus, including the portion in the neck

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
McKeown Esophagectomy


 All of esophagus removed

 Connection made in the neck

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Risks of Esophagectomy
Esophagectomy is a complex operation, with a real risk of complications.
Two significant complications:

Anastomotic leak
Pneumonia

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Anastomotic Leak


The anastomosis is surgical connection between the esophagus and the stomach.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Anastomotic Leak


If healing doesn’t occur:

Leakage of fluid from the esophagus
Infection in the space between the lungs
Requires additional time in the hospital

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Anastomotic Leak


If leak occurs:

Some leaks will seal
Stent may be required to help healing
Occasionally additional surgey is required

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Anastomotic Leak


Risk of leak depends on:

Type of operation performed
Nutritional status of patient
Experience of the surgeon

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Pneumonia



Occurs in 10-15% of patients after esophagectomy.
Requires treatment with antibiotics
Requires a longer hospitalization.

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Preventing Pneumonia
Several ways to help prevent pneumonia:

Deep breathing
Coughing
Walking

After surgery, this means:

Sitting in a chair most of the day
Walking in the halls as soon as possible

Goal: ready to leave day #6/7 after surgery

Night-time tube feedings (6pm to 10am)
Nutrition by mouth (70% of patients)

1 oz of water per hour by mouth OR
Protein shakes 4oz every 2 hours

Water through tube 8oz four times per day
Home care nursing (feeding tube teaching)
Home infusion (tube feeding supplies)

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:

At discharge home:

Protein shakes 4oz every 2 hrs
Tube feeds 4-5 cans at night (6pm-10am)

10-12 Days: Increase protein shakes

Tube feeds 3-4 cans at night

Three weeks: Post-esophagectomy Diet
8-12 weeks: Remove feeding tube (in office)

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Transition from Tube Feeds \(\rightarrow\) Eating
Dietitian will calculate daily protein goal

Typically 60-75 grams protein/day
Each carton of tube feeding has 15 grams

75 grams protein = 5 cartons/night

More intake by mouth \(\rightarrow\) tube feeds reduced

Spread out protein during the day (20gm/meal)

Three meals + 2-3 high-protein snacks

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:

Soft Consistency
High Protein
Avoid sugary liquids (can cause ‘dumping’)
Avoid raw vegetables (and salads)
Eating

Small, frequent meals
Sit up for 30-45 minutes after eating
Avoid eating within 2 hours of bedtime

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Medicines at Home - Pain
Acetaminophen (Tylenol) 1000mg 4x/day
Gabapentin 300mg 3 times/day
Oxycodone

As needed in addition to Tylenol/gabapentin
Will begin reducing dose at first postop visit
Can usually discontinue by 4 weeks
NO DRIVING WHILE ON OXYCODONE

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Non-steroidals Anti Inflammatory (NSAID)
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatories (Celebrex)

200 mg every 12 hours starting at 2 weeks

NO GOODY POWDERS OR BCs

(Can cause permanent scarring at the surgery site)

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Acid Blockers = Proton Pump Inhibitors
Examples include ompeprazole and pantoprazole

Will stay on for at 1-2 years to prevent acid reflux
Important in preventing scarring at anastomosis (new connection between esophagus and stomach)
To administer through feeding tube, open capsule and resuspend beads in 60mL (2oz) of water

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Medicines at Home
Reglan – Helps stomach empty

Will plan to stop after six weeks
0.1% risk of tardive dyskinesia (nervous tic)

Remeron – Helps improve appetite

Can cause vivid dreams
Used for several weeks after surgery
Will stop within first three months of surgery

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Metoprolol = Beta Blockers

Slows heart rate and lowers blood pressure

Used to prevent rapid heart rate
Patients not taking a beta blocker prior to surgery \(\rightarrow\) wean after after surgery
Patients taking a beta blockerprior to surgery \(\rightarrow\) return to prior dose and drug after surgery

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction
text:
Sleeping at Home


Reflux can occur the first few weeks/months after surgery
This improves over the first few months
A wedge pillow can be helpful for sleep

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction

Check surgical site

Remove staples (if needed)

Adjust medicines as needed

Insulin (for diabetic patients on insulin)
Reduce beta blocker medicines

Advance diet
Reduce tube feeds

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction

Wean off medicines added after surgery

Pain medicines
Beta-blockers
Reglan and Remeron

Continue acid blockers for at least 1 year

title: Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus and GE Junction

Jejunostomy Removal
Jejunostomy tube is removed in the office once you can take in enough nutrients by mouth
Removal usually around 8 weeks after surgery
May take 30 minutes and some local anesthetic to loosen up the tube for removal.

title: Central Venous Port
text:
Cancers or all kinds are frequently treated with chemotherapy or immunotherapy drugs which need to be administered through the veins.
I’m Dr Jonathan Salo, I’m a GI Cancer Surgeon.
In this video you’ll learn about the different methods of intravenous drug administration

title: Central Venous Port
text:
Cancers or all kinds are frequently treated with chemotherapy or immunotherapy drugs which need to be administered through the veins.
I’m Dr Jonathan Salo, I’m a GI Cancer Surgeon.
In this video you’ll learn about the different methods of intravenous drug administration

title: Central Venous Port
text:
2 Types. L 4
There are three options for intravenous administration of drugs:

Peripheral Intravenous line (which is likely familiar to most people)
PICC Line or Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter
Central Venous Port (commonly referred to as a Port-a-Cath)

title: Central Venous Port
text:
3 Peripheral IV 2
A peripheral IV is placed through the skin into a vein in the hand or forearm.
The catheter is removed the same day and then replaced when it’s time for the next dose, which is typically one to three weeks later.
For patients who receive FLOT chemotherapy, a peripheral IV is not suitable because this treatment requires a 24-hour infusion of drug.

title: Central Venous Port
text:
4 PICC LIne
A PICC line is a special intravenous line with a long tube that brings drugs to the veins near the heart.
This catheter can be left in place for several weeks.
It is suitable for FLOT chemotherapy
The disadvantage of the PICC line is that that dressing needs to be kept dry as long as the catheter is in place.

title: Central Venous Port
text:
5 Central Venous Port
A Central Venous Port is a small device which is surgically placed underneath the skin.
It contains a small chamber with a flexible rubber top and a tube that goes into the veins near the heart
When it comes time to administer drugs, a needle is passed through the skin into the chamber

title: Central Venous Port
text:

Port placement can be combined with other procedures such as diagnostic laparoscopy or feeding tube placement

title: Central Venous Port
text:
10 Central Venous Port Insertion (10)
Typically, the port is placed in the operating room under sterile conditions. A 1 inch incision made below the collar bone, and frequently a smaller incision is made in the neck. The procedure is done an an outpatient, so you can go home the same day.
The care of a port after surgery is very easy, as there are no tubes outside the body to worry about.
The sutures are all under the skin and will dissolve on their own. The incision should be dry for at least 24 hours. We recommend no heavy lifting for the first week to avoid bruising.
Typially, the incisions will be covered with a surgical glue which will flake off after a week or so.

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Chemo + Radiation CROSS Trial
Typical schedule for chemotherapy + radiation:

Chemotherapy once per week for six weeks
Radiation five days per week for six weeks (28)



PET scan (or CT) 4 weeks after the end of radiation




Surgery 8 weeks after the end of radiation

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:

Kills cancer cells in the esophagus and lymph nodes
Can also irritate the lining of the esophagus.

Swallowing can be difficult the last 2 weeks.


Feeding tube may be needed for hydration/nutrition.

Central Venous port

Removed that day

No special care at home
OK for FLOT chemo

Sutures dissolve
“Superglue” on incisions

Surgery performed after restaging

Endoscopy after Initial Therapy
Performed to look for signs of persistent cancer
Biopsies show no cancer in 75% of cases
Disappearance of cancer in 40% of cases - Persistent cancer in 60%
\(\Rightarrow\) cancer cells can hide in the wall of the esophagus
Regular endoscopy is important to look for regrowth of cancer

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:

Surgery is recommended for all patients who have:

Biopsies showing cancer after chemo + radiation
No signs of spread of disease on PET/CT scan
Healthy enough to undergo surgery

Surgery is also recommended for patients who:

No signs of spread on disease on PET/CT scan
Cancer in the lower part of the esophagus
Healthy enough to undergo surgery

Upper endoscopy (EGD) every 3-6 months
PET every 6 months

\(\Rightarrow\) Surgery if a recurrence in the esophagus is found

Working hard enough that you can’t converse

Surgery for esophageal cancer is performed for:

Superficial Tumors (T1) not removed by endoscopy
Localized Tumors (T2 N0 M0)
Locally Advanced (T3 M0) after preop therapy

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Goals of Surgery



Remove tumor from esophagus
Remove surrounding lymph nodes
Create a new esophagus

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Ivor Lewis (Transthoracic) Esophagectomy



Removes tumor and lower 1/3 esophagus
Removes surrounding lymph nodes
GI tract reconstructed

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Reconstruction


New esophagus is created from the stomach in the abdomen by fashioning it into a tube.

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Ivor Lewis esophagectomy


The new esophagus is now brought up into the chest. A connection is made between the esophagus and the stomach, called an anastomosis.

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Minimally-invasive Ivor Lewis



Small incisions abdomen and chest
Surgical telescope and instruments
Smaller incisions \(\rightarrow\) faster recovery and less discomfort

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Open Ivor Lewis


Mininally-invasive approach feasible in 95% of cases
In some cases, an open approach is still necessary.

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Total Esophagectomy


For patients with tumors in the upper esophagus, we need to remove more of the esophagus
We need to remove the whole esophagus, including the portion in the neck

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
McKeown Esophagectomy


 All of esophagus removed

 Connection made in the neck

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Risks of Esophagectomy
Esophagectomy is a complex operation, with a real risk of complications.
Two significant complications:

Anastomotic leak
Pneumonia

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Anastomotic Leak


The anastomosis is surgical connection between the esophagus and the stomach.

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Anastomotic Leak


If healing doesn’t occur:

Leakage of fluid from the esophagus
Infection in the space between the lungs
Requires additional time in the hospital

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Anastomotic Leak


If leak occurs:

Some leaks will seal
Stent may be required to help healing
Occasionally additional surgey is required

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Anastomotic Leak


Risk of leak depends on:

Type of operation performed
Nutritional status of patient
Experience of the surgeon

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus

Pneumonia



Occurs in 10-15% of patients after esophagectomy.
Requires treatment with antibiotics
Requires a longer hospitalization.

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Preventing Pneumonia
Several ways to help prevent pneumonia:

Deep breathing
Coughing
Walking

After surgery, this means:

Sitting in a chair most of the day
Walking in the halls as soon as possible

Arrive at 5am – nothing to eat or drink after midnight.
Medicines OK w/ a sip of water
sip of black coffee but no cream.

Waiting room for family and friends on 5th floor

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Epidural Catheter for Pain Control

Remains in place for 2-5 days
Dosage can be adjusted as needed
Can make it more difficult to urinate
May require foley catheter in bladder
Foley catheter removed after epidural removed

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Intensive Care Unit (ICU) (2-4 days)

Surgical ICU on 11th floor
NG tube in nose to drain stomach and esophagus
Catheter in bladder
Chest tube right chest
Abdominal drains (usually 2)
Feeding jejunostomy (usually stays in 8 wks)

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Intensive Care Unit (ICU)

Bladder catheter removed → check that bladder empties properly
Chest tube removed (day 2-4) → follow-up x-ray
Fluid emptied from drains every few hours
Start tube feedings by feeding
Feeding jejunostomy (stays in 8 weeks)

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Ward - 6Tower

Jejunostomy feeds started
Up in a chair most of the day
Walking in the halls

Start with assistance
Improves lung function
Prevents loss of muscle strength

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Jejunostomy Feeds
Jejunostomy tube feeds

Start continuous (24 hours)
Convert to night-time only (16 hours)

Water administered through feeding tube

Usually 8oz 4 times/day
Important to prevent dehydration

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Jejunostomy Tube



Nutrition to bypasses the esophagus and stomach
Placed in small intestine
Pump administers feedings slowly
Feeding done at night

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Jejunostomy Typical Regimen

Jejunostomy tube feeds for 16 hours (6pm-10am)

Men: 75mL/hour x 16 hours = 5 cartons
Women: 60mL/hour x 16 hours = 4 cartons

Water 240ml (8oz) via syringe 4x/day

Hospital nurses will teach use of the feeding tube

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Jejunostomy Feeds with Diabetes
Jejunostomy feedings elevate blood sugars

Insulin may be required along with feeds

Typical Pattern for tube feeds

Feeds run via pump from 6pm to 10am
Insulin at 6pm (70/30 insulin)
Insulin at Midnight (70/30 insulin)
No insulin if tube feedings are not run

text:

text:

Up in chair most of the day
Walking with help from nurse/Physical Therapist
Goals:

Improve lung function
Prevent muscle loss

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Nasogastric (NG) Tube
Tube passed through nose into stomach

Drains fluid from stomach
Prevents vomiting

Upper GI X-ray on 2nd or 3rd day after surgery

If stomach empties well \(\rightarrow\) NG tube removed
Otherwise, X-ray repeated 2-3 days later

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:

Once NG tube has been removed:
Modified barium swallow in radiology

Drink a white chalky liquid (barium)
Look for proper swallowing function
70% of patients \(\Rightarrow\) liquids started by mouth

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:

Most are taking protein shakes when they go home
Protein shakes are started after tolerating water


2 oz per hour to start
4 oz per hour if 2oz are tolerated well

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Discharge
Goal: ready to leave day #6/7 after surgery

Night-time tube feedings (6pm to 10am)
Nutrition by mouth (70% of patients)

1 oz of water per hour by mouth OR
Protein shakes 4oz every 2 hours

Water through tube 8oz four times per day
Home care nursing (feeding tube teaching)
Home infusion (tube feeding supplies)

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Nutrition after Surgery
At discharge home:

Protein shakes 4oz every 2 hrs
Tube feeds 4-5 cans at night (6pm-10am)

10-12 Days: Increase protein shakes

Tube feeds 3-4 cans at night

Three weeks: Post-esophagectomy Diet
8-12 weeks: Remove feeding tube (in office)

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Transition from Tube Feeds \(\rightarrow\) Eating
Dietitian will calculate daily protein goal

Typically 60-75 grams protein/day
Each carton of tube feeding has 15 grams

75 grams protein = 5 cartons/night

More intake by mouth \(\rightarrow\) tube feeds reduced

Spread out protein during the day (20gm/meal)

Three meals + 2-3 high-protein snacks

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Post-esophagectomy Diet

Soft Consistency
High Protein
Avoid sugary liquids (can cause ‘dumping’)
Avoid raw vegetables (and salads)
Eating

Small, frequent meals
Sit up for 30-45 minutes after eating
Avoid eating within 2 hours of bedtime

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Medicines at Home - Pain
Acetaminophen (Tylenol) 1000mg 4x/day
Gabapentin 300mg 3 times/day
Oxycodone

As needed in addition to Tylenol/gabapentin
Will begin reducing dose at first postop visit
Can usually discontinue by 4 weeks
NO DRIVING WHILE ON OXYCODONE

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Non-steroidals Anti Inflammatory (NSAID)
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatories (Celebrex)

200 mg every 12 hours starting at 2 weeks

NO GOODY POWDERS OR BCs

(Can cause permanent scarring at the surgery site)

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Acid Blockers = Proton Pump Inhibitors
Examples include ompeprazole and pantoprazole

Will stay on for at 1-2 years to prevent acid reflux
Important in preventing scarring at anastomosis (new connection between esophagus and stomach)
To administer through feeding tube, open capsule and resuspend beads in 60mL (2oz) of water

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Medicines at Home
Reglan – Helps stomach empty

Will plan to stop after six weeks
0.1% risk of tardive dyskinesia (nervous tic)

Remeron – Helps improve appetite

Can cause vivid dreams
Used for several weeks after surgery
Will stop within first three months of surgery

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Metoprolol = Beta Blockers

Slows heart rate and lowers blood pressure

Used to prevent rapid heart rate
Patients not taking a beta blocker prior to surgery \(\rightarrow\) wean after after surgery
Patients taking a beta blockerprior to surgery \(\rightarrow\) return to prior dose and drug after surgery

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Sleeping at Home


Reflux can occur the first few weeks/months after surgery
This improves over the first few months
A wedge pillow can be helpful for sleep

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Postoperative Visit at 7-10 Days
Check surgical site

Remove staples (if needed)

Adjust medicines as needed

Insulin (for diabetic patients on insulin)
Reduce beta blocker medicines

Advance diet
Reduce tube feeds

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
After surgery
Wean off medicines added after surgery

Pain medicines
Beta-blockers
Reglan and Remeron

Continue acid blockers for at least 1 year

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Jejunostomy Removal
Jejunostomy tube is removed in the office once you can take in enough nutrients by mouth
Removal usually around 8 weeks after surgery
May take 30 minutes and some local anesthetic to loosen up the tube for removal.

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus

You may have difficulty absorbing some nutrients:

Iron
Vitamin B12
Vitamin D

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
text:
Nutritional Monitoring after Surgery
About 3 months after the jejunostomy tube is removed, we will check blood levels:

Iron (ferritin)
Vitamin B12
Vitamin D

Primary Care Provider (PCP)
Medical Oncologist
Surgeon

If levels are low

Replacement
Repeat testing in 3-6 months

4 Staging
A PET or CT scan is used for staging. If the scans show that the tumor is localized, without signs of spread beyond the nearby lymph nodes, it is considered M0.
On the other hand, if the scans show signs of spread, this is considered Metastatic Disease or M1. (4)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
5 Metastatic Disease = M1
Patients with metastatic disease are best treated with chemotherapy and are generally not treated with surgery. (5)

We will focus in this video on Locally-advanced cancers

text:
7 Locally-advanced Esophageal Cancer T2/3 or N+.
Locally advanced esophageal cancer has not spread to other organs in the body. Locally-advanced cancers are not only M0, but they are either T2 or T3 or node-positive. (7)
If this terminology is not familiar to you, please refer to our video on Diagnosis and Staging. There is a link above and in the description below.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
8 Locally-advanced: M0
Locally-advanced cancers are M0, which means there is no evidence of metastasis, or spread to other parts of the body. (8)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
9 Adenocarcinoma vs Squamous Cell.
To make things a bit more complicated, there are two types of esophageal cancer: Adenocarcinoma and Squamous Cell Carcinoma. The treatment of there cancers is somewhat similar, but different enough that we have prepared a video to specifically address squamous cell carcinoma. (9)

text:
11 Why not just Cut it out?
I am occasionally asked by patients why we don’t just remove esophageal cancer with surgery as the first treatment. (11)
The answer is a bit complex.

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
12 
When a patient is diagnosed with cancer of the esophagus or gastroesophageal junction, it can look like the cancer is confimed to the esophagus. (12)

and kill cancer cells in the surrounding area
This therapy typically involves chemotherapy (17)

18 Locally Advanced
and may involve radiation (18)

19 Locally Advanced
The overall goal is shrinking the tumor and killing nearby cancer cells, to make the surgery more effective (19)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
20 Surgery
After preoperative therapy has shrunk the tumor and any other cancer cells, surgery can be performed

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Preoperative therapy combined with surgery offers the best chance to remove all of the cancer, without leaving any behind (21)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
22 Post Surgery and Reconstruction
…without leaving any cancer cells behind (22)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
23 Preoperative Therapy 4

Shrinks the tumor
Make surgery more effective
Leads to better cancer control than surgery alone (23)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
24 Neoadjuvant
You may hear preoperative therapy referred to as “neoadjuvant therapy” (24)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
25 Preop Therapy
For squamous cell carcinoma, chemotherapy and radiation are delivered at the same time before surgery (25)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
26 Chemotherapy + Radiation -> Surgery
The chemotherapy and radiation strategy uses chemotherapy and radiation together
Chemotherapy is given intraveneously once per week
Radiation is given five days per week
Both are administered together for 5 1/2 weeks
This is also know as the “CROSS” treatment regimen (26)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
27 Chemotherapy + Radiation -> Surgery
The chemotherapy is a low dose, designed to make the radiation more effective
The therapy is generally well tolerated
Hair loss is uncommon
Low blood counts are also uncommon, and occur in about 7% of cases

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
28 Radiation Esophagitis
The radiation can, however, cause inflammation in the esophagus called esophigitis.
This can make eating more uncomfortable during the last two weeks of radiation (28)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
29 Radiation Esophagitis
The good news is that this is temporarily and usually resolves within 2 or 3 weeks after the radiation is completed. (29)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
30 Radiation Esophagitis
What this may mean, however, is placement of a temporary feedindg tube may be needed. (30)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
31 Radiation Esophagitis
The feeding tube can usually be removed 2-3 weeks after the end of radiation, as the cancer shrinks and the inflammation subsides (31)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
32 Chemo + Radiation -> Surgery 2
To summarize, This approach to preoperative therapy uses six weeks of chemotherapy and radiation together.
Surgery is typically performed 6-8 weeks after the end of radiation, as soon as patients have recovered. (32)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
33 Chemo + Radiation -> Surgery
After surgery, the pathologist examines the cancer that has been removed.
One of the things the pathologist looks for is how well the preoperative chemotherapy and radiation killed the cancer before the surgery
In some cases, the pathologist doesn’t find any cancer that looks alive. (33)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
34 Chemo + Radiation -> Surgery
After surgery, the pathologist examines the cancer that has been removed.
One of the things the pathologist looks for is how well the preoperative chemotherapy and radiation killed the cancer before the surgery
In some cases, the pathologist doesn’t find any cancer that looks alive. (34)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
35 Chemo + Radiation -> Surgery
In about half the cases of patients treated with chemotherapy and radiation, followed by surgery, the pathologist does not find any evidence of live cancer cells in the specimen (35)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
36 Chemo + Radiation -> Surgery
In these cases, the cancer was probably cured by the chemotherapy + radiation alone (36)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
37 Chemo + Radiation
Patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus are cured by chemotherapy and radiation alone in about half of cases. (37)

title: Locally-Advanced Esophageal Squamous Cell Carcinoma
text:
38 Chemo + Radiation
It can be hard to know for certain who is cured immediately after the chemotherapy and radiation are finished (38)

51 Preparing for Preoperative Therapy-2
I know this all sounds rather complex, but the starting point is to get prepared for chemotherapy and radiation.
There are three important ways:
First is to make sure you take in enough protein in your diet. We have a video on nutrition.
Second is to stay active. We recommend 30minutes each day of vigorous exercise such as brisk walking
Third is to be careful about your dental hygeine. If you need any dental work done, check with your dentist. Keeping your teeth healthy can reduce the risk of infection during therapy. (50)
